cells.text: Compare the level of highlights with my intended words and tones, then adjust them.

I only used it as an indicator of how the LLM interpreted its own tone, as it was pretty clear to me that the type of adjectives the model used were weighed more heavily then the actual contents of the sentences. As an example a sentence containing something similar to: "his incredible stupidity" would be interpreted as positive because the model thinks incredible is a positive word and ignores the rest of the sentence contents.
I'd be more direct regarding the content I want out of a paragraph
i did not use it as i doubt whether it accurately reflects the tone of those sentences. Sometimes the tone indicated by "this feature" is inconsistent with my perception.
it helped me understand the structure of the answers better and help identify how positive or negative the answers are.

I will not only observe sentences marked with colours, but also study the content of sentences that are not marked. Often, AI will show a particular bias in specific topics.

When I was using it for negative paragraphs, I could see how sentences are negatively expressed. It helped me to focus on the ones that I would love to adjust and make them get close to my expectation as possible.

I use the color-coded text to better understand how the system interprets my input and adjusts the content accordingly. However, there are times when I don't notice any visible change in the colored text after making adjustments. This can reduce my trust in the system and may lead me to ignore the colored text in future interactions. That said, overall, it still helps me align the paragraph with my intended goal more easily.
I will familiarize myself with the expression characteristics of AI based on the highlights and then change the way I ask questions.

In this experiment I could've used this feature to make sure all sentences align with the intended tone. To me it would be more interesting in real-world uses. It would help in recognizing the tone of the sentences more clearly, since sometimes it's not very apparent what the tone is. Because of this, it makes it easier to change the sentences that I feel need adjustment to match my desired tone.

It would be especially helpful when writing balanced arguments, instead of ones that are fully negative or fully positive. In this context, the color-coded sections could quickly show me where the for-arguments and against-arguments are.
If this feature were available, I would use it to encode or categorize my text content

I did not notice this feature during the experiment; however I believe that it can help users reflect on the tone they want to convey, while at the same time making them aware that content is never purely 'neutral' and devoid of emotions. "Positive" or "negative" tone impacts our experience of content, and the meaning we give to it. This type of feature, therefore, can be helpful for adapting text to a specific audience and conveying emotions

I had a good example where I found this feature surprisingly useful. When i had to write positively and it started off negative, when I asked the chatbot to change it into a positive text, it kept some negative content in it. For example, it still stated every possible health condition that was wrong with the type of dog breed I wanted to write positive about. Using this feature, I could easily change the text that was wrong, while keeping the rest the same.

I used this feature as a tool to assist in structuring and refining my writing. First, I outlined my main ideas and input them into the system. Then, I used the feature to rephrase and expand these ideas into coherent paragraphs. It helped ensure clarity, correct grammar, and smooth transitions between sentences. Throughout the process, I reviewed and edited the output to maintain my original voice while enhancing overall quality.

cells.text:
For academic/professional writing, something to keep track of links/citations would be helpful. I would want to make sure I'm not plagiarizing, but also that I'm faithfully capturing the main points of the resources in a neutral (unbiased) tone. Then I can use those as building blocks to provide my own opinions (positive or negative) after that.

For more casual writing (like on social media), I wouldn't reach for a chatbot's help, or at least not part of the first draft attempt.

I think sometimes the tone evaluation provided by the app doesn’t align with my own judgment, and this inconsistency adds to my cognitive load and leaves me feeling confused. Personally, I usually use AI to generate content with a more neutral tone, focusing on factual accuracy rather than adding strong emotions. cells.text: Please take a look at my other response.

Well, I think some explanation in the questionnaire should be moved to the instruction at the beginning of the app. A picture of the whole panel and explanation of each figure and botton should be explained before the usage. Some point that may lead to confusions should also be pointed out more clearly at the very begining and during the usage like the inaccurate highlighting color of the tone of each sentence.
tags: more instruction on how to use

cells.text: I like this design. It is very helpful for writing.
No, it is good though.
I think the design and thinking of this app is innovative.
i probably prefer not using visualisations. A liitle bit redundant.
tags: prefer not to use because of redundant

cells.text: I basically like the design, but I am not sure if it is possible to change the colour of the tones, as for now the green represented negative tones and the red represented positive tones, but sometimes I felt a bit confused as the red was like a sign of warning or mistake. I guess the blue or the yellow would be better for telling the difference of the tones.
tags: hope to have the ability of modify the color meter

cells.text: Sometimes it confuses me. Maybe the topic I posted wasn't clear enough.
I like it combining attitude inside, it would be more useful
it is confusion to choose the neutural, slight off and so on. my choice may be affected by the content. and the level of word i hope could be lower.
I think the content and language expression are still not natural enough.
too many colour made me feel hard to read
I like it, as it can help with change the tone easily.
no
like this design , can make writing neutral
The app bugged out on the second question, recovered after page reload.

I found the paragraphs written by the chatbot to lack a personal touch. The design of the app is clean and easy to follow. The only thing that could be improved is the visual structure of the consent form information, as I found it a bit confusing.
tags: Do not like the writing style(lack of personal touch)

cells.text: Sometimes I thought I could change the sentences after agreeing with the content, but this made me continue to the next step of the survey. I caught on quickly, so it wasn't a big issue.

It was not clear to me at the beginning that double clicking sends an additional prompt that I could just send on my own and the note did not help it. The design was really great though, just as for a typical chatbot. I like that there are "emotion" confidence values.
The design was pretty good overall. I would have liked to have the prompt remain at the top of the page or something to remind me of the goal of each paragraph (topic + positive or negative).
tags: would like to have a reminder on certain part of the page to emphasize the goal(topic/positive/negative)

cells.text: I did read about the double click feature at the start, however for me as someone who had not any of the extra visualizations, maybe some extra visual clue/small tutorial to use the double click feature could help. I don't think this is needed for the version with visualizations, because it is made more obvious with colourized text. The design of what I saw in the pictures looked very good/easy to use/clear
I think the design of the first four questions can be clearer. At first I was not aware of the experience intended design
tags: more instruction on how to use

cells.text: I think visualizations could be better utilized for data processing rather than just simple text.
tags: could be utilized for data processing

cells.text: i think it's like a AI. do you understand. it can give you some clear concept. but sometimes AI can provide some emotions. such as if i mentioned negatived things i hope it can provides me some answers, like i really understand what you experienced.
I didn't see any of the visualization features, but that might have been my bad
the app is kind of confusing.
It was quite interactive and well-designed.
These features have already done a great job on the visualisation work.
no

I did not see in the experiment some of the features showed in the questionnaire. Perhaps this is actually part of the experiment and done on purpose, but it made me curious about these features that I did not notice. Some of the screenshots/visualizations in the questionnaire are a bit too small, which makes it difficult to see/read. Other than that, I really appreciated your experiment (especially because we previously discussed about it during a meeting, and it was great to see the final product!)
tags: confused because some of the feature's not available

cells.text: It was slightly confusing at the beginning because, for the second visualization technique, namely the distribution plot, it didn't find legends indicating which color was before or after the change, but it was easy to figure out anyway as I moved the cursor to the sentences.
it's creative for me
The design is simple and I quite like it
no more

I was somewhat confused at first, because I had to mark if it aligned, but that confusion was quickly resolved. I think it's good to have such adaptive features, and especially to have an indicator of the tone. However, I do think that writing your own piece without AI would still be best.
tags: more instruction on how to use
